text: Would anyone be kind enough to do me a quick TLDR?

text: As I see it, anyone over 40% rate will benefit. Anyone ON 40% with 100k+ profit in last year will be slightly worse off due to implied commission drop to 2,5%. Newbies will hit 40% rate faster if they are successful. Oldies on sub 100K a year on the 40% rate will drop to 20% so be better off. Just my interpretation though.

text: Was _anyone_ here consulted or asked about the change to PC to EF? Did Betfair ask any PC payer at any level in this group about whether they thought this would be good/bad/level for a) their own commission and/or b) other players in the market?

elements.text: Was
anyone

here consulted or asked about the change to PC to EF? Did Betfair ask any PC payer at any level in this group about whether they thought this would be good/bad/level for a) their own commission and/or b) other players in the market?

text:
<@U012XF5CNPN> I don't have a breakdown of what percentage of PC payers fall into which brackets, but is it perhaps fair to say that if the majority are 40% payers making 100K+ a year (I've only seen one person on this slack admit to being in the 50% range and NONE at 60%) then the only REAL change they experience is the implied commission reduction to 2.5%. Given that this is supposed to reflect the "true" average commission rate across the exchange now (as mentioned in the docs) and they were going to reduce it anyway, perhaps they felt that consultation was pretty pointless?? Those at 50%+ are already going to be happier, as are those at 40% who make less than 100K a year.
Just a theory - maybe they just don't care what anyone thinks.

text:
Now this might total guff, but I noticed that Caan Berry got this thread up VERY fast suggesting that he might have had some prior info?
<https://x.com/CaanBerryTrader/status/1869360646657282125>

attachments.fallback: X (formerly Twitter): Caan Berry (@CaanBerryTrader) on X
attachments.text:
Betfair announced an "Expert Fee" will replace the "Premium Charge" as of 6th January 2025...

New thresholds:
- £25,000 year to qualify
- £100,000 per year to qualify for 40%

In reality, it changes nothing really.

They must be getting desperate...
attachments.title: Caan Berry (@CaanBerryTrader) on X

elements.text: Now this might total guff, but I noticed that Caan Berry got this thread up VERY fast suggesting that he might have had some prior info?

text: Ok I think I see the logic of it from BF's perspective - encourage lower margin players to stay interested and bring in volume, bigger winners aren't going anywhere anyway so make up the difference in PC (which won't be much) by shifting implied comm. why not.

elements.text: Ok I think I see the logic of it from BF's perspective - encourage lower margin players to stay interested and bring in volume, bigger winners aren't going anywhere anyway so make up the difference in PC (which won't be much) by shifting implied comm. why not.

text: It's not like they need more of us.

elements.text: It's not like they need more of us.

text: Everyone needs counter-parties. Liquidity is dripping away, so long-term they need more smart money talking at each other with different takes on how to be smart (there's likely more than one or two ways to make money in highly volatile 102%/98% offer/bid spreads). By saying "OK, let's gear everything around BA Pro manual traders" - and that's what I'm trying to understand, if _*that*_ is the main audience they're working backwards from - they're taking quite a punchy move on how to get liquidity back into markets.

text: Probably my naivety on display, but if they want to attract new money rather than half-arsing things in this fashion why not tier raw commission on winnings and bin the PC completely? New players on 0% up until £X profit made. I'm probably missing something obvious but this feels like it will have no impact on improving liquidity at all :man-shrugging:
